RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Possui graduação em Ciência da Computação pela Universidade Federal do Espírito Santo (2003), mestrado em Informática pela Pontifícia Universidade Católica do Rio de Janeiro (2005) e doutorado em Informática pela Pontifícia Universidade Católica do Rio de Janeiro (2009). Professor da Universidade Federal de Goiás. Tem experiência na área de Ciência da Computação, com ênfase em Redes de Computadores e Sistemas Distribuídos
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: graduate at Ciência da Computação from Universidade Federal do Espírito Santo (2003), master's at Computer Science from Pontifícia Universidade Católica do Rio de Janeiro (2005) and ph.d. at Computer Science from Pontifícia Universidade Católica do Rio de Janeiro (2009). Professar at Federal University of Goiás. Has experience in Computer Science.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: UNIVERSAL 423212/2021-4: Aplicações de Formalismos Lógico-Semânticos em Programação Concorrente e Redes Móveis de Próxima Geração
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Descrição: Nowadays, concurrent systems (i.e. systems of agents or processes that interact with each other) are ubiquitous in several domains and applications. They are commonplace in different areas, ranging from biological systems to mobile and cloud services. In general, concurrent systems exhibit complex forms of interaction, e.g. those found in models for biology, interactive multimedia systems, social networks or IoT devices. Frameworks for specification/verification of such systems must also scale up to cope with larger systems and more involved properties. The current project aims at the application of Formal Methods in different aspects of concurrent systems development. In particular we investigate two application domains: concurrent programming and next generation mobile networks. Great challenges posed by today's systems can be found in either system: nested locations created in cloud systems; autonomous creation and management of slices in next generation mobile networks; and proper type systems for programming languages supporting concurrency. Giving rigorous foundations to these systems is a serious challenge for Computer Science. We require both: to faithfully capture the behavior of the studied system (i.e., the evolution of the system is in one-to-one correspondence to reductions/derivations in the model); and to offer reasoning techniques for the verification of systems' properties. In fact, we plan to use complementary approaches for dealing with the inherent complexity of those systems: declarative models for concurrency and rewriting logic. Besides, session types will play a role in an operational/denotational investigation of concurrent programming languages..
